True, 'is_visible': True}, 'plugging_driver': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'convert_to': convert_validate_driver, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, } } A ``hosting_device_template`` and ``hosting_device`` can be CRUD by admin users. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None to existing. This device manager service plugin uses its own RPC for interactions with Cisco configuration agents. These agents are defined in [1]_ The resource manager service plugin to config agent RPC notifications consists of the following functions:: def agent_updated(self, context, admin_state_up, host) def hosting_devices_unassigned_from_cfg_agent(self, context, ids, host) def hosting_devices_assigned_to_cfg_agent(self, context, ids, host) def hosting_devices_removed(self, context, hosting_data, deconfigure, host) The function names is indicative of their purpose. The config agent to resource manager service plugin RPC callbacks consists of the following functions:: def report_non_responding_hosting_devices(self, context, **kwargs) def register_for_duty(self, context, **kwargs): The first callback is used to report if a hosting device is determined to be "dead". The second one is used during configuration agent startup. It ensures that the agent framework report from the config agent is processed by Neutron server before the agent is given responsibility for any hosting devices. Other end user impact --------------------- The ``python-neutronclient`` will be extended to with commands to CRUD hosting device templates and hosting devices: ``cisco-hosting-device-template-<`` *operation* ``>``, ``cisco-hosting-device-<`` *operation* ``>``, where *operation* = ``[create, show, list update, delete]`` Performance Impact ------------------ None for the worse. Device manager service plugin and other service plugins that make use of configuration agent should rather help to reduce load on Neutron server due to reduced agent reporting traffic and offloaded device interactions. Other deployer impact --------------------- The deployer will have to specify that the new device manager service plugin be used. Then other service plugins will have to be able to interact with the device manager service plugins. During Juno cycle a router service plugin will be completed that has this capability (see blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/cisco-routing-service-vm). Developer impact ---------------- Readers who actively follow or engage in the Neutron community will find that this blueprint in parts have similarities with the service VM framework effort and its blueprints [3]_. This is no coincidence as there has been some exchange of thoughts between the two efforts even though they have so far progressed in parallell. There are therefore at this point in time also differences, largely in implemenation details. This is partially also due to the fact that the efforts have focused on different use cases (LBaaS and routing). The legacy of those services along with various other constraints have also led to somewhat different implementation choices. For Juno cycle it is not realistic to achieve any real consolidation of these two efforts. However, for later releases it is desirable to attempt some unification of the two implementations. Implementation ============== The below figure shows the new device manager service plugin and the components it interacts with. The hosting device template boxes are objects in the database and are just to show that the hosting device plugin knows about a certain number of hosting device templates from which hosting devices can be created/registered . :: .......................................... ............. .............. . Neutron . . Some . . Nova . . Server . . Server . . Compute . . . . . . . . . . . . +-------+ . . . . . . |Hosting| . . . . . +---->|Device | . . +-----------------------------------+ . . . | . |Svc VM | . . | Device Manager Service Plugin | . . . | . +-------+ . . | | . RPC . +------+ . | .............. . | +--------+ | NOTIFIC. |Config|<---+ . | +--------+| +------------------+ |<-------->|Agent | . Device specific . | +--------+|| |Hosting -> Config | | CALLBACKS| |<---+ protocol (e.g., . | |Hosting ||| |Device Agent | | . . +------+ . | Netconf, REST) . | |Device ||+ | SCHEDULER | | . . . | . | |Template|+ +------------------+ | . . . | +-------+ . | +--------+ | . . . | |Hosting| . +-----------------------------------+ . . . +---->|Device | . . . . |HW unit| .......................................... ............. +-------+ **The slot notion** Logical resources of different types (Neutron Router, Neutron Firewall etc) may consume non-equal amounts of resources (like RAM, CPU, or TCAMs) inside the hosting device. For example, basic routing may be less resource hungry than firewalling with lots of filtering rules. Therefore a hosting device may only be able to host a select set of logical resource combinations. These constraints must be taken into account in scheduling of logical resources to hosting devices. To allow for this in a simple, yet flexible way, this blueprint uses the notion of abstract slots and the associated ‘slot_capacity’ and ‘slot_availability’ metrics. The ‘slot_capacity’ is an integer metric representing the processing capacity of a hosting device. This metric is not intended to be comparable across hosting devices stemming from different hosting device templates. Hence, hosting devices A and B, based on hosting device templates TA and TB, respectively, may have the same ‘slot_capacity’ value. But this does not necessarily imply that A and B are equally powerful in absolute terms. One can think of that slot notion as somewhat similar to the *EC2 Compute Unit* in Amazon's EC2 [2]_. It is the responsibility of the producer of a device to define the ‘slot_capacity’ for such devices so that it can be stored in corresponding hosting device templates. A Hosting device created from hosting device template has a ‘slot_availability’ attribute that is set to the ‘slot_capacity’ of the template as initial value. When a logical resource type is defined, which involves associating that type to a hosting device template, the number of slots the logical resource needs must be specified. For the case of Neutron Routers this slot need is stored by the Cisco router service plugin [4]_ in a ``routertypehostingdevicetemplatebinding`` table’s ``slot_need`` column. The same approach can be used for other Neutron services like Firewall or VPN. When a service plugin requests slot allocation or deallocation for one of its logical resources it should use the device manager service plugin’s functions: ``acquire_hosting_device_slots(self, context, hosting_device, id, num)`` and ``release_hosting_device_slots(self, context, hosting_device, id, num)``, respectively. In the former function, the hosting device should preferably be one that was determined to be a possible candidate by a scheduling invocation (immediately) preceding the allocation request. In the latter function, the service plugin should ensure that the hosting device is indeed hosting the logical resource for which the slots are de-allocated. The device manager API provides the service plugins with a way to signal potential shortage of hosting devices (of a certain type). They can call the Hosting device manager’s function ``report_hosting_device_shortage(self, context, host_type, category)``. For example, the Cisco routing service plugin calls that function when scheduling has failed to find a hosting device to host a Neutron Router. **The device lifecycle management** The device manager service plugin is oblivious to logical resources. It essentially only cares about hosting devices and slots in those devices. How logical resources consume slots allocated to them is left to the different service plugins to manage. Those service plugins on the other hand are not supposed to involve themselves in how or when hosting devices are created (or registered) in the running deployment. Those tasks are the responsibility of the device manager service plugin. The above described separation of concerns between the existing service plugins and the new device manager service plugin simplifies the implementation. It also facilitates resource sharing between service plugins. For hosting devices in the ‘Hardware’ category the life cycle management is very limited. It involves only some rudimentary fault management whereby the status of a hardware-based hosting device is set to reflect an error state. For hosting devices in the ‘VM’ category (basically service VMs) the life cycle management performed by the Hosting device manager is more comprehensive. The device manager service plugin starts VMs and destroy VMs automatically with the objective that some number of service VMs should be available at all times for immediate usage. The reason for a pool is that service VMs take time to boot into operational state. It is not unusual that this delay can amount to 5 or even 10 minutes. The pool makes it possible to hide such delays from the users of the Neutron service. Overall result is improved user experience and more predictable response times. Hence, the slot notion is also used for life cycle management. By monitoring the total number of available slots per hosting device type the device manager service plugin knows if more slots are needed in the pool or if slots should be removed from the pool. This monitoring is piggybacked on the functions described earlier by which slots are acquired or released and hosting device shortage is signaled. To increase the number of slots additional service VMs are created, and to decrease the number of slots, unused service VMs are destroyed. Unused here means that the service VM is not hosting any logical resources so none of its slots have been allocated. Fault management for service VMs is different from hosting devices in the ‘Hardware’ category. A faulty service VM instance is removed device manager service plugin: it is unregistered as a hosting device and Nova is asked to destroy the VM. **Hosting device drivers** In order to make a device useful as a hosting device there might be operations that need to be performed on it (or on behalf of it) by the device manager service plugin.To support operations that are common to hosting devices regardless of Neutron environment but need to be performed in a device specific manner the device manager service plugin uses so called hosting device drivers. While the Hosting device driver API currently only contains functions to create and delete files to injected into service VM hosting devices via Nova’s configdrive features, more can be added in the future as need arise. A hosting device driver should implement all functions in the API but make non-applicable ones perform no operations. Hence, hosting devices in the ‘Hardware’ category would use hosting device drivers where the functions coupled to the use of configdrive perform nothing. **Plugging drivers** When a hosting device is created or deleted and when a logical resource implemented inside a hosting device is attached or detached from a Neutron Network/Subnet, a number of things related to connectivity need to happen. Because of the coupling to connectivity these operations have a dependency on the Neutron environment, basically the core plugin in use. This blueprint abstracts those operations under a plugging driver API that the device manager service plugin and the other Neutron service plugins can use. Basically, a driver for a hosting device of certain type must be developed for the Neutron environment is will be used in. It is very possible, even likely, that a plugging driver may be suitable for multiple types of devices. For example, a plugging driver for a virtual machine-based appliance will probably work for other such VM appliances. The current API for plugging drivers, in short, includes functions that deal with creation/deletion of port resources for hosting devices, mapping a logical resource’s ports to those of its hosting device and, finally, establishing/tearing down connectivity for logical resources residing in the hosting devices. To explain the reasoning behind the plugging driver API consider the case where a logical resource, say a Neutron Router, is attached to a Neutron Subnet. A Neutron Port for the logical resource must then be created and this allocates an IP address in the subnet in question. That can be viewed as the logical port for the logical resource, see the figure below. Now, suppose that a hosting devices in the form of a VM managed by Nova. Attachment of such VMs to Neutron Networks also requires Neutron Ports. The Cisco N1kv plugin supports Neutron Ports that carry VLAN tags. While this offers a very scalable way to attach a VM (and logical resources implemented inside it) to many Neutron Networks it also complicates matters from a modeling perspective. :: +----------+ . +---------+ | | . | | | Logical | . | Hosting | | Resource | . | device | | | . | | +----+-----+ . +---------+ | . | | . | | . | | . | o . o Logical port . Hosting port . . Logical port is the . Hosting port may be other Hosting port may be the Neutron Port created . than the Logical port. Logical port. for the logical . Example: Service VM with Example: Service VM with resource (e.g., . VIF that trunks networks VIF dedicated to Logical Neutron Router). . port The current approach taken is to introduce the notion of *hosting ports*. The logical port must be mapped to its hosting port. In the plugging driver API this is done by the following function:: allocate_hosting_port(self, context, resource_id, port_db, network_type, hosting_device_id) This function can be viewed as a scheduler of the logical ports. We allow the hosting port to be the same Neutron port that represents the logical port. This makes the logical port/hosting port construct applicable to additional use cases like the important ones listed in Figure 5. The binding between logical port and hosting port is stored in the ‘hostedhostingportbindings’ table. Scheduling the logical port is not enough. L2 configuration in the (virtual and/or physical) switch infrastructure is needed for that logical port. This is a step that the Neutron core plugins typically handle. However, when VLAN tagging on the Neutron Ports for a service VM-based hosting devices is used, additional configuration is needed. With the aim to handle such cases but also to support other scenarios, the plugging driver API provides two generic functions: ``setup_logical_port_connectivity(self, context, port_db)`` and ``teardown_logical_port_connectivity(self, context, port_db)`` An example of the how the setup function can be used is illustrated in the below figure. There, a service VM-based hosting device like the Cisco CSR1kv appliance is used to host Neutron Routers. The router is implemented as a VRF inside the VM. :: Logical operation: Implementation in Implementation in Neutron Router attached N1kv plugin with plugin without to Neutron Subnet trunk support: trunk support: +-------+ +-------------+ +-------------+ |Neutron| Hosting| Service VM | Hosting| Service VM | |Router | Device | | Device | | +---+---+ | +-----+ | | | | | | VRF | | | | | | | | | | +-----+ | | | +-L---+ | | | VRF | | | | I | | | | | | | FV | | +-V---+ | | +-----I-------+ +----I--------+ | F F | | | | Trunk VLAN | Hotplug to | Attach to | for Neutron| Neutron | subnet! | Network! | Network! | -----------V----------- +---V-----+ +--V------+ Neutron Subnet/Network | vSwitch | | vSwitch | +---------+ +---------+ In a Neutron environment with the Cisco N1kv plugin, establishment of connectivity for a Neutron Router hosted inside the CSR1kv VM instance can make use of the N1kv plugins VLAN trunking feature. This is not possible with other Neutron (core) plugins, e.g., Openvswitch or Linuxbridge plugins. Therefore, establishment of connectivity in the N1kv case amounts to trunking an additional network on the Neutron Port (of the Hosting device) that hosts the Neutron Router’s logical port. For plugins lacking the VLAN trunking feature, hot-plugging of VIFs might be relied on instead. In that case the Neutron Router’s logical port may be the Neutron port created for the service VM. Consequently, the establishment of connectivity involves instructing Nova to hotplug the VM to the created Neutron Port. Other examples, in particular logical resources hosted in ‘Hardware’ category devices, have been found to be compatible with the plugging driver API. This indicates that it is a promising abstraction albeit changes to it are not unlikely as new types of hosting devices or Neutron constructs are introduced. The reader may note that a final crucial step is needed to make an attachment operational and that is configurations inside the hosting device. However, that is not the responsibility of plugging drivers. Instead, the config agent asynchronously performs all such tasks. For completeness a figure also showing the new router service plugin is shown below:: .......................................... ............. . Neutron Server . . Some . . . . Server . . +----------------------------------+ . . . .............. . | Device Manager Service Plugin | . . . . Nova . . | | . RPC NOTIFICATIONS . Compute . . | +--------+ | . & CALLBACKS . . . . | +--------+| +-----------------+ |<--------------+ . . +-------+ . . | +--------+|| |Hosting -> Config| | . . | . . |Hosting| . . | | Hosting||| |Device Agent | | . . | . +---->|Device | . . | | Device ||+ | SCHEDULER | | . . | . | . |Svc VM | . . | |Template|+ +-----------------+ | . . V . | . +-------+ . . | +--------+ | . . +------+ . | .............. . +----------------------------------+ . . |Config|<---+ . . . |Agent | . Device specific . +----------------------------------+ . . | |<---+ protocol (e.g., . | Router Service Plugin | . . +------+ . | Netconf, REST) . | | . . | . | . | +------+ | . . | . | +-------+ . | +------+| +------------------+ | . . | . | |Hosting| . | +------+|| |Neutron -> Hosting| |<--------------+ . +---->|Device | . | |Router||+ |Router Device | | . RPC NOTIFICATIONS |HW unit| . | |Type |+ | SCHEDULER | | . & CALLBACKS . +-------+ . | +------+ +------------------+ | . . . . +----------------------------------+ . . . .......................................... ............. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: bob-melander Other contributors: hareesh-puthalath, skandasw Work Items ---------- Code for review can be submitted for review shortly. Dependencies ============ Devstack and Neutron client must and will be updated to support this plugin. Testing ======= Unit tests will be added for all new functionality. We are currently exploring how to best perform functional and scenario tests. Documentation Impact ==================== Will require new documentation in Cisco sections. References ========== .. [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/cisco-config-agent. .. [2] https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/faqs/ .. [3] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/cisco-routing-service-vm .. [4] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/adv-services-in-vms

commit_message:
Describes design of hosting device to config agent scheduler

- Introduces hosting device to configuration agent scheduler.
- Introduces REST API for admin user interactions with the new scheduler.

  cfg-agent-scheduler

Change-Id: I85bfbe11f947092b2ae57965737e444bb7af1e82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/18/91918/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Scheduler for hosting devices to configuration agents ===================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/cfg-agent-scheduler Problem description =================== There is need to support Neutron services implemented in virtual machines (and hardware devices). Such devices need to be made available to Neutron service plugins so they can instantiate the resources they define (e.g., Router, Firewall etc) there. The life cycle of such devices must be managed. This is particularly obvious for the case virtual machine devices. This life cycle management can includes creating or registering devices as well as monitoring the health of them. With many devices also being multi-service capable and Neutron now including a variety of service plugin types that operate independently of each other, efficient resource management is a challenge. There is also a need to improve the scalability of Neutron to better handle large deployments and intense usage patterns. Reducing the load of the Neutron server, both by in terms of the control traffic it needs to handle and the number of tasks it has to perform, improve scalability. The blueprints device-manager-service-plugin [1]_ and cisco-config-agent [2]_ describe new architectural components introduced to tackle the above needs and challenges. The figure below illustrates the components defined in the two blueprints and their relation. :: .......................................... ............. .............. . Neutron . . Some . . Nova . . Server . . Server . . Compute . . . . . . . . . . . . +-------+ . . . . . . |Hosting| . . . . . +---->|Device | . . +-----------------------------------+ . . . | . |Svc VM | . . | Device Manager Service Plugin | . . . | . +-------+ . . | | . RPC . +------+ . | .............. . | +--------+ | NOTIFIC. |Config|<---+ . | +--------+| +------------------+ |<-------->|Agent | . Device specific . | +--------+|| |Hosting -> Config | | CALLBACKS| |<---+ protocol (e.g., . | |Hosting ||| |Device Agent | | . . +------+ . | Netconf, REST) . | |Device ||+ | SCHEDULER | | . . . | . | |Template|+ +------------------+ | . . . | +-------+ . | +--------+ | . . . | |Hosting| . +-----------------------------------+ . . . +---->|Device | . . . . |HW unit| .......................................... ............. +-------+ The *device manager service plugin* manages devices that are capable of hosting Neutron services and control the allocation of processing capacity in such devices. The *configuration agent* monitors devices and applies configurations inside them. RPC notifications and callbacks are used for communication between the plugin and agent. This allows them to run on different servers. A deployment needs at least one configuration agent. Additional configuration agents can be used if the number of hosting devices is large. Since a deployment may grow over time or even temporarily due to usage peaks it is desirable that configuration agents can be added without disruption to the operatioal cloud. Proposed change =============== To meet the requirements in the last paragraph of the previous section this blueprint introduces a scheduling component for inclusion in the device manager service plugin. The scheduler can be seen in the figure in the previous section. This new scheduler component is closely modeled after the l3 agent scheduler so readers familiar with it will notice many similarities. In summary the change involves: - Introduction of hosting device to configuration agent scheduler. - Introduction of REST API for admin user interactions with the new scheduler. Alternatives ------------ For small deployments with a single agent a scheduler is of limited value. An alternative for such use cases could have been to just specify the agent to use in Neutron's configuration file. However, since large deployments with multiple config agents is to be supported we have concluded that a scheduler is the appropriate solution. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- A new extension 'cisco-cfg-agent-scheduler' adds REST API actions to learn which config agent a hosting device has been scheduled to, which hosting devices a certain config agent handles, and to change such associations. The REST API operations are only available to admin users. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None to existing. This device manager service plugin uses its own RPC for interactions with Cisco configuration agents. The scheduler related RPC notifications from the resource manager service plugin to a config agent consist of the following functions:: def hosting_devices_unassigned_from_cfg_agent(self, context, ids, host) def hosting_devices_assigned_to_cfg_agent(self, context, ids, host) The function names is indicative of their purpose. Other end user impact --------------------- The ``python-neutronclient`` will be extended to with commands to associate/ disassociate a hosting device with a config agent. ``cisco-cfg-agent-list-hosting-device``: Lists cfg agent handling hosting device ``cisco-cfg-agent-hosting-device-add``: Adds hosting device to cfg agent ``cisco-cfg-agent-hosting-device-remove``: Remove hosting device from cfg agent ``hosting-device-list-on-cfg-agent``: Lists hosting devices handled by cfg agent Performance Impact ------------------ None for the worse. Device manager service plugin and other service plugins that make use of configuration agent should rather help to reduce load on Neutron server due to reduced agent reporting traffic and offloaded device interactions. Other deployer impact --------------------- The deployer can specify the scheduler module to be used but there is a default value for the configuration option. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Similarly to the L3 agent scheduler implementation two classes are used to handle the REST API processing: ``class HostingDeviceSchedulerController(wsgi.Controller)`` ``class CfgAgentsHandlingHostingDeviceController(wsgi.Controller)`` A mixin class ``CfgAgentSchedulerDbMixin`` implements DB functionality. It inherits the ``agentschedulers_db.AgentSchedulerDbMixin`` for integration in the Neutron agent framework. Finally there is a scheduler driver that perform the actual scheduling actions by randomly selecting a config agent for a hosting device. A new configuration option ``configuration_agent_scheduler_driver`` allows the scheduler driver to be changed. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: bob-melander Other contributors: hareesh-puthalath, skandasw Work Items ---------- Code for review can be submitted for review shortly. Dependencies ============ Devstack and Neutron client must and will be updated to support this scheduler component. Testing ======= Unit tests will be added for all new functionality. We are currently exploring how to best perform functional and scenario tests. Documentation Impact ==================== Will require new documentation in Cisco sections. References ========== .. [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/device-manager-service-plugin .. [2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/cisco-config-agent

commit_message:
Describes design of routertype aware router scheduler

- Evolves l3agent scheduler to be routertype-aware.
- Adds slot notion compatible Neutron Router to hosting device scheduler.

  router-scheduler-to-hosting-devices

Change-Id: Ie6361cc78358ffa27f498b555c357c0f2dba67d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/04/92004/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Scheduler for Neutron routers to hosting devices ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/router-scheduler-to-hosting-devices Problem description =================== There is need to support Neutron's routing service implemented in virtual machines (or hardware devices). The blueprint cisco-routing-service-vm [1]_ describes a new router service plugin that is able to do that. It introduces ``routertype`` resources and adds a ``routertype_id`` to Neutron routers. A routertype is associated with a certain type of hosting devices. Users can specify the kind of Neutron Router they want by setting the ``routertype_id`` in the router create REST API call. The router service plugin described above extends the current reference implementation and also supports the current Linux network namespace-based Neutron Routers. That reference implementation is typically deployed with a l3 agent scheduling component that makes it more feature-rich and flexible. The blueprint device-manager-service-plugin [2]_ introduces the notion of *slots*, which is an abstract metric for processing capacity in hosting devices. The new router service plugin has been designed to be compatible with the slot notion. Because of the introduced routertype notion and that the new router service plugin builds on the reference implementation and further, is to be compatible with the slot notion, a *scheduling component* is needed that: - Is compatible with the new plugin's functionality, in particular routertypes. - Is able to schedule Neutron routers to hosting devices in a slot-aware manner. - Can make use of the existing l3agent scheduling. This bluprint describes the design of such a scheduling component to be used by the new router service plugin. Proposed change =============== - Introduction of ``class L3RouterTypeAwareScheduler`` that inherits and extends ``l3_agent_scheduler.L3Scheduler``. - Introduction of ``class L3RouterTypeAwareSchedulerDbMixin`` that inherits and extends ``l3agentsched_db.L3AgentSchedulerDbMixin``. - Introduction of ``router_type_aware_scheduler_driver`` configuration option. - Introduction of ``class L3RouterHostingDeviceScheduler`` which schedules hosting device-based Neutron Routers to hosting device taking account slot usage. Alternatives ------------ The flavor framework being discussed and defined has clear similiarities with the routertype notion. Some aspects of the scheduler problem is also similar. However, we need a near-term solution. Once the reference router service plugin is properly modularized and aligned with the flavor framework, we can adapt to that in the form of a vendor driver. Data model impact ----------------- None. Data models that this BP relies are introduced in blueprints [1]_ and [2]_. REST API impact --------------- The current l3 agent scheduler REST API remains intact. In the first phase covered by this blueprint no REST API is added specific for Neutron Router to hosting device scheduling. There will be a second phase covered by *another* blueprint that introduces a new extension "router_hosting_device_scheduler". It defines a REST API for the Neutron Router to hosting device scheduling akin to the l3agent scheduler. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- The new router service plugin uses its own RPC for interactions with Cisco configuration agents [3]_. Further it uses the RPC of the reference implentation for interactions with L3 agents. All of the RPC notifications are contained in a ``class L3RouterJointAgentNotifyAPI``. It is both routertype-aware and topic-aware. Other end user impact --------------------- None for this blueprint. In conjunction with the second phase changes the neutronclient will require changes to support the API provided by the "router_hosting_device_scheduler". Performance Impact ------------------ None foreseen. Other deployer impact --------------------- We believe this will have no impact on community L3 router service plugin, not in its current implemenation, nor when DVR is merged. The deployer will have to specify that the Cisco routing service plugin be used instead of the community one. A configuration agent must also be deployed. The new configuration option ``router_type_aware_scheduler_driver`` has a default value that can be relied on in most deployments. The scheduler to be used for l3 agent scheduling is specified by the regular ``router_scheduler_driver``. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== The below figure shows the new/evolved Neutron router scheduler in the new router service plugin. The routertype boxes are objects in the database and are just to show that the router service plugin knows about a certain number of routertypes that users can request. :: .......................................... ............. .............. . Neutron . . Some . . Nova . . Server . . Server . . Compute . . . . . . . . . . . . +-------+ . . . . . . |Hosting| . . . . . +---->|Device | . . +----------------------------------+ . . . | . |Svc VM | . . | Router Service Plugin | . . . | . +-------+ . . | | . RPC . +------+ . | .............. . | +------+ +------------------+ | NOTIFIC. |Config|<---+ . | +------+| |Neutron-+->Hosting| |<--------->|Agent | . Device specific . | +------+|| |Router | Device | | CALLBACKS | |<---+ protocol (e.g., . | |Router||+ | +->L3Agent| | . . +------+ . | Netconf, REST) . | |Type |+ | SCHEDULER | | . . . | . | +------+ +------------------+ | . . . | +-------+ . +----------------------------------+ . . . | |Hosting| . . . . +---->|Device | . . . . |HW unit| .......................................... ............. +-------+ Scheduling of Linux network namespace-based Neutron routers is done as part of sending L3 agent notifications similarly to the reference implementation. Scheduling of Neutron Routers in hosting devices is also coupled to the sending of notifications. However it happens when information is assembled about the router for which the notification concerns. Finally, scheduling can also happen when a L3 agent or configuration agent perform a RPC callback to router service plugin. For completeness a figure also including the device manager service plugin is shown below: :: .......................................... ............. . Neutron Server . . Some . . . . Server . . +----------------------------------+ . . . .............. . | Device Manager Service Plugin | . . . . Nova . . | | . RPC NOTIFICATIONS . Compute . . | +--------+ | . & CALLBACKS . . . . | +--------+| +-----------------+ |<--------------+ . . +-------+ . . | +--------+|| |Hosting -> Config| | . . | . . |Hosting| . . | | Hosting||| |Device Agent | | . . | . +---->|Device | . . | | Device ||+ | SCHEDULER | | . . | . | . |Svc VM | . . | |Template|+ +-----------------+ | . . V . | . +-------+ . . | +--------+ | . . +------+ . | .............. . +----------------------------------+ . . |Config|<---+ . . . |Agent | . Device specific . +----------------------------------+ . . | |<---+ protocol (e.g., . | Router Service Plugin | . . +------+ . | Netconf, REST) . | | . . | . | . | +------+ +------------------+ | . . | . | +-------+ . | +------+| |Neutron-+->Hosting| | . . | . | |Hosting| . | +------+|| |Router | Device | |<--------------+ . +---->|Device | . | |Router||+ | +->L3Agent| | . RPC NOTIFICATIONS |HW unit| . | |Type |+ | SCHEDULER | | . & CALLBACKS . +-------+ . | +------+ +------------------+ | . . . . +----------------------------------+ . . . .......................................... ............. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: bob-melander Other contributors: hareesh-puthalath, skandasw Work Items ---------- Code for review can be submitted for review shortly. Dependencies ============ Devstack must be updated to support this plugin. Testing ======= Unit tests will be added for all new functionality. Functional and scenario tests for community L3 implementation will be useful also for this implementation. Documentation Impact ==================== Will require new documentation in Cisco section. References ========== .. [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/cisco-routing-service-vm .. [2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/device-manager-service-plugin .. [3] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/cisco-config-agent

commit_message:
Adds specification for provider-router blueprint

This blueprint specifies a Neutron API extension that provides a way to
map and register distant non-OpenStack routers to the Neutron database,
allowing them to be used by tenants with complete API support.

Change-Id: Ia4c0dbf64fa21c0fb03598c4b9951c312a96dd61
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/25/91925/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================= Neutron Provider Router Extension ================================= Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/provider-router Specify a Neutron API extension that provides a way to map and register distant non-OpenStack routers to the Neutron database, allowing them to be used by tenants with complete API support. Work in progress (WIP). Problem description =================== Such functionality will ease integration and on-demand connectivity between legacy network infrastructures and cloud-provided virtual networks, also useful for incrementally migrating from the former to the latter. In the context of this blueprint: provider router, distant router, distant provider router, physical router and legacy router all share the same meaning. To avoid confusion with the `existing provider router term <http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/install-guide/install/yum/content/ section_networking-provider-router_with-provate-networks.html>`_, the "distant provider router" or "DPR" terms will be preferred throughout this document. Currently, the integration of existing physical/legacy components with a virtual environment is of vital importance to allow the migration of currently deployed (legacy) infrastructures to new networking clouds (public/private). The main use cases are thus related to connecting physical environments to virtual ones through a legacy network that cannot be easily changed. * Connect a virtualized environment to distant physical networks on demand; * Have physical hosts on a private physical network being able to reach VMs on a private virtualized environment; * Have a router connected to at least two different networks: a directly connected one and a distant virtualized one (located at the cloud) but nevertheless seen as directly connected; * Maintain addressing and reachability unchanged from the legacy network's perspective, i.e., everything looks as though the (now virtual) physical network is still there (and still physical). Proposed change =============== There are three main points to consider for the implementation of this extension: 1. Who/what is responsible for communicating changes to the physical routers; 2. How to communicate with physical routers: * This should be extensible in order to support any router; 3. How router interfaces will be connected to tenant networks: * The traffic between the VMs and the physical routers should be isolated; * The traffic must stay on the same IP network; Regarding the first point, it can be achieved using a special agent, built as per https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/quantum-l3-routing-plugin, called DPR Agent (DPR: distant provider routing, not to be confused with just DPR: distant provider router). When an operation is executed (e.g. ``router-interface-add``) the agent will communicate that change to the correspondent physical router. For the second point, the management of the physical routers will be done through a driver implementing a generic interface. This will keep the software easily extensible and enable the use of any equipment from a linux box to a carrier grade router by implementing the respective driver. The driver implementation will be up to its creator and dependent on the physical router characteristics. It may use a management interface, through telnet or ssh, the SNMP protocol, or any other mechanism that is appropriated. This driver is connected to the DPR agent plugin, implementing its interface for drivers. For the third point, the technology used to connect the router to the tenant network (e.g. GRE) is determined by the DPR agent plugin in use and **must be supported both by the L2 plugin used in the compute nodes (e.g. ML2) and the distant provider router**. An example of a physical machine at the legacy side of the distant provider router communicating with the virtual side of the distant provider router, using ML2 and network type GRE, is presented in the following diagram: :: +---------------------------------+ +---------------------------------+ | Network Node | | Compute Node | | | | | | +-----------+ +-----------+ | | +-----------+ | ML2 | | ML2 | +-----------+ | | | L3 Agent +-------+ | | +-------+ VM | | | +-----------+ | | | | +-----------+ | | | | GRE | | | | | +-------+ | | | | | | | | | +-----------+ GRE | | | | +-----------+ | | | DPR Agent +-------+ | | +-------+ VM | | | +-----+-----+ | | | | +-----------+ | | | +-----------+ +-----------+ | | | | | | | | | | | +---------------------------------+ +---------------------------------+ | |GRE | | +---------+ +-----+-----------------------+ GRE | | +----------------+ | Any network, hops, +------+ Distant +------+ Legacy Network | | aka Internet | | Router | +---+--------+---+ +-----------------------------+ | | | | +---------+ | | +-----+--+ +--+-----+ |Physical| |Physical| |Machine | |Machine | +--------+ +--------+ Reachability with the physical networks at the other side of the distant provider router should be straighforward, as machines will be configured with some gateway IP address either manually or by DHCP, exactly the same as in a typical environment. Alternatives ------------ Although deploying a VPN, possibly with Neutron's VPNaaS, could serve a similar purpose, the objective is to maintain the legacy network as untouched as possible, configuring everything from the OpenStack side and making sure the 4th use case above is possible. Data model impact ----------------- The database model extension is shown in the diagram below. It adds a new table to keep track of the distant provider router's specifics. This table contains the IP address used to reach the router, which might be somewhere on the Internet, and router type, to select the driver used by the DPR agent to decide how to apply configurations to the router (as explained previously). :: +---------------------+ +---------------------+ | | 0..1 1 | | | Router +--------------------------------+ DPRouter | | | | | +---------------------+ +---------------------+ | | | router_type: string | | reach_addr: string | | | +---------------------+ REST API impact --------------- The provider-router blueprint extends the Neutron API by creating new attributes. No new resources or actions are defined. However, the structure of a ``router`` will be extended with 2 new attributes in the ``provider`` namespace. +---------------------+-------+---------+------------+--------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Conversion | | +=====================+=======+=========+============+==============+ |provider:router_type |string |CR |string |will match | | | |admin | |a driver | +---------------------+-------+---------+------------+--------------+ |provider:reach_addr |string |CRU |ipv4 or |to reach | | | |admin |ipv6 format |the router | +---------------------+-------+---------+------------+--------------+ * ``provider:router_type`` specifies the type of router. This will be used to choose the driver that will handle the communication with the physical router; * ``provider:reach_addr`` specifies the IP address used to reach the router, which might be somewhere on the Internet. Authorization ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ By default, distant provider routers can only be created or deleted by admin users. The provider attributes are also only visible, and can only be updated by admins.This routers can nonetheless be assigned to any tenant. The tenant will then be able operate the router the same way it operates a virtual router. Security impact --------------- TODO Notifications impact -------------------- TODO Other end user impact --------------------- Performance Impact ------------------ TODO Other deployer impact --------------------- A new configuration variable is necessary to provide the mapping between the router_type and the correspondent driver. The variable ``provider_router_driver_mapping`` will go to the ``dpr_agent.ini`` file. This will be further analysed before a implementation is finished. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: igordcard Other contributors: fmanco, dgomes, cgoncalves Work Items ---------- The objective is to merge this extension into OpenStack (milestone target) by juno-1. The implementation will be divided in the following work items: * API modifications; * CLI modifications; * Changes to the database model and related code; * Sketch the driver interface; * Implement DPR Agent: * Tenant network support; * router:external network support; * Floating IPs support; These will be performed in individual commits to be sent for review. Dependencies ============ Regarding Python dependencies, the extension itself doesn't have any specific requirements. However it is possible that the used DPR agent drivers introduce new requirements. It is expected that, to manage the routers, drivers will use telnet (https://docs.python.org/3.4/library/telnetlib.html), SSH (https://wiki.python.org/moin/SecureShell), SNMP (http://pysnmp.sourceforge.net) or other technologies. Testing ======= TODO Documentation Impact ==================== TODO References ========== None

commit_message:
remote group rules optimization for host addresses.

Change-Id: Ic552ac94545640fc8c6519a78ae528c10d4772a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/41/131641/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ﻿.. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================================== Default Remote Groups Rule Summarization Solution ============================================================================== The idea of this proposal is to summarize the Host Addresses[/32] into Connectionless Inter Domain Routing[CIDR] notation which results in optimization of rules being provisioned on the IpTables/OVS Firewall. Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: None Problem description =================== In the Open stack solution, one of the major scalability bottleneck is provisioning the default remote group rules. Optimization is done to avoid the load of the Controller(Neutron Server) by introducing new RPCs which reduces the message exchange Payload. However, there are no solution at the Agent side to optimize the default remote security group rules which are predominantly HOST Addresses [/32] based. If the HOST addresses are in consecutive VM Ipaddress range, chances of summarizing is very high and good thing is DHCP is used in Open stack deployment, which will provide consecutive IP for VMs. Proposed change =============== To address the above challenge, the proposed solution require changes in the L2 agent module. Default remote secuirty group rules HOST addresses are summarized into CIDR addresses using Rule Summarization Engine. This engine is designed using Python Netaddr's "cidr_merge(ip_list)" method. For each VM Ports, the rule engine takes a set of remote group HOST rules based on the protocols such as IP,ICMP,TCP,UDP,SSH,IPv6,ICMPv6 etc.,creates CIDR rules for the supported protocols and these CIDR rules will be used for provisioning the IpTable/OVS Firewall. In the current solution, default remote security group allows all Egress traffic and very few rules are required to support the Egress rules. However for Ingress traffic, Host address rules of the remote VMs are added or deleted whenever new VMs are being provisioned/de-provisioned or new security group rules are added/deleted. This explicit rules are the potential candidate for summarizing. This solution targets the Ingress Host addresses for summarizing, which results in maximum reduction in the number of rules to be processed at the IP Table/OVS Firewall. This rule reduction numbers could come down by ~70-80%. Alternatives ------------ Existing solution works without this optimization however it will not scale. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Data Traffic performance will improve because few rules are stored in IpTable/OVS firewall for matching. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Singh, Gangadhar Other contributors: A, Keshava P,Rashmi Shenoy, Raghuveer Work Items ---------- OVS L2 agent implementation L2 agent IpTable Driver OVS firewall Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added. Existing tempest will be updated/added. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will be updated. References ========== None

commit_message:
Fixing broken while loop in imports.py

Issue: flake8 occasionally encounters "H302  import only modules."
error even though the python module exists at the path and python
shell is able to import the same.

Root-cause: The while loop in is_module_for_sure() had a bug, where
iterating variable, 'mod_name', was getting derived from the same
input, 'mod', every time. It should have led to an infinite loop
otherwise. But, an ImportError takes it out of the loop. Most of
the cases, this is not an issue, if as part of the exception handler,
built-in __import__() finds the module. The evidence of the issue is
the availability of import statements suffixed with "# noqa" to
work-around the bug.

Fixing the while loop causes the logic to flow in the original path of
the code to use 'imp.find_module()'

Change-Id: I83d80b1cf6961568e825d4387443b285e490fb40

commit_message:
Repeated erase and reboot for bootstrap nodes

If Atute got unxepecting status 'bootstrap'
from node in the middle of provision operation,
we try to erase and reboot node. In mostly
enviroments where this bug was reproduced
this operation was enough to solve problem.

If, for some reason, this does not help, we
can with great confidence to look at the
problem in Cobbler.

Change-Id: I9ffaa885bd150a6fa119f07bc04b79bd5afb92a1
Closes-Bug: #1318567
(cherry picked from commit 122cdaab63357dc2138f01c89637c4188ad831ed)

Ignore playground directories for translation

Skip playground directories, those are for testing and will not get
translated at all.
Use regex for skipping of directories instead of long or list.

commit_message:
Revert "Glance: remove deprecated config options"

This reverts commit 4265520b4c5e3ce9877f9cf88bef955e42855440.

There were no warnings generated in the logs when using these
deprecated options so removing them was premature.
Related-Bug: #1390427

Change-Id: Id9882d15eb4be503bd847dbbce5a6f3d68798961
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/133212/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

PYTHON_HASH_SEED=0 is needed because these tests apparently remain

Change-Id: I742c487dd7bca9de3e811c545de477367fff112c
'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-11-26 18:15:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7ff2d213f956bda0fbd65d27f535e937d70f7e46', 'message': "move the integrated tests into the functional tree

This moves the integrated tests into the functional tree as an initial
seed for the functional tests. It was agreed to as an early step at
the design summit. Work on cleaning these up will happen after the
move.

PYTHON_HASH_SEED=0 is needed because these tests apparently remain
order dependent.

Also remove the use of test.ReplaceModule, which is an untested
mocking system in the nova tree that doesn't seem to reliably
work. Use stubs instead for the time being, as this will ensure
repeatability of the code.

Part of bp:functional-tests-for-nova

Change-Id: I742c487dd7bca9de3e811c545de477367fff112c

commit_message:
move the integrated tests into the functional tree

This moves the integrated tests into the functional tree as an initial
seed for the functional tests. It was agreed to as an early step at
the design summit. Work on cleaning these up will happen after the
move.

PYTHON_HASH_SEED=0 is needed because these tests apparently remain
order dependent.

Also remove the use of test.ReplaceModule, which is an untested
mocking system in the nova tree that doesn't seem to reliably
work. Use stubs instead for the time being, as this will ensure
repeatability of the code.

Part of bp:functional-tests-for-nova

Change-Id: I742c487dd7bca9de3e811c545de477367fff112c

commit_message:
Horizon container implementation

Horizon requires that Nova, Neutron(Nova Network), Glance,
and Keystone are running.  Therefore, the container needs to
check for the availablity of each service on startup.

The config file is not a .ini file, but rather a python file
so it requires using sed instead of crudini.

Change-Id: I5ed14514881fe9aef688ca08bcb94881ef5b25cb

commit_message:
Cap Oslo and client library versions

We've agreed to start capping the versions of libraries used in the
stable branches to more accurately reflect what we expect to be used in
a stable deployment, and to allow those libraries to release new versions
without risking breaking stable deployments.

This patch introduces caps for the Oslo and client libraries to their
current major.minor+1 value (assuming semantic versioning). There will
be another patch to update all of the third-party libraries.

Change-Id: I2d5697871d5750f37399b5b60a92297cbf69d6b5

commit_message:
Improve storage capabilities

Change-Id: I560a98fefd1dca28182aefc5343f3eab982991a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar-specs refs/changes/31/126531/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/zaqar/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ============================= Expose storage capabilities ============================= Flavors allow operators to expose some of the internal storage capabilities without giving the exact details of how the system is configured. As of now, the operators has total control over what capabilities are exposed to the user regardeless on whether these capabilities are indeed guaranteed or valid. A `capability` is a feature that is either specific to the storage or to Zaqar - durable, fifo, in-memory, for example - and they can be enabled/exposed in a per-flavor basis allowing end-users to choose the best flavor for a specific queue. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/zaqar/+spec/expose-storage-capabilities Problem description =================== Flavors are very powerful when it comes to give choices to end-users without taking control out from operators. However, there's no way for operators to know what capabilities each storage driver has, which makes this feature completely custom to whatever the operator thinks makes more sense. It's important to support operators on the choice of what features are exposed to the end-users through the API by making it clear which are supported by the drivers that have been deployed. Moreover, this is also important for doing a proper capacity planning based on the use-cases the service is trying to support. Proposed change =============== Capabilities ------------ This change request proposes defining a set of internal `capabilities` and a way for storage drivers to expose which capabilities are supported so that operators may know in advance what a flavor would support and what storage drivers they may need. The set of internal capabilities includes: - FIFO - AOD (At least once delivery) - high-throughput Exposing Capabilities --------------------- This capabilities should be exposed by the storage driver iff supported. This spec proposes adding a new class method to the base class called `capabilities` that should return a set with a list of supported `capabilities`. The capabilities returned in this set cannot be custom, which means they must be supported internally.:: @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class DataDriverBase(DriverBase): ... @classmethod def capabilities(self): return self._CAPABILITIES Drivers Load ------------ In addition to the above-mentioned changes, we also need a better way to load drivers based on the capabilities. That is, when drivers are loaded, it's necessary to pass down to the driver the capabilities that have been enabled per-flavor so that the driver itself can be specialized for some capabilities. In most of the cases, loading a driver will end up in always loading the same implementation. However, there are cases - FIFO, for example - where more specialized implementations may be needed depending on the storage. Therefore, instead of *always* loading the `DataDriver`, this spec proposes adding a new `get_driver` function that will let the storage itself load a driver according to the capabilities passed there.:: def get_driver(plane='data', capabilities=None): ... This means we won't need to register neither `DataDriver`s nor `ControlDriver`s as `entry_points` but just the new `get_driver` function. This will allow storage driver's to expose fewer things as public API's. A variant for the above `get_driver` proposal would be.:: def get_drver(base=base.BaseDataDriver, capabilities=None): ... This way we can avoid giving 'names' to this planes and just ask what we need in terms of 'signature'. However, it makes loading the actual driver a bit more complex and it'll also duplicate some logic across different storage drivers. Alternatives ------------ Keep it custom and do nothing. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: flaper87 Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: K-1 Work Items ---------- * Define list of internal capabilities and document it * Add required abstractions to storage drivers to expose the supported capabilities * Let flavor's pass the capabilities down to the storage driver when it's being loaded. Dependencies ============ .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Create initial ansible deployment repository

A project to work on Ansible playbooks for OpenStack deployment.

We'll start with all playbooks in the one place while we figure out
the full architecture. We intend to set up Ansible linting and
testing in a later change.

As a starting point, we're seeding from
https://github.com/rcbops/ansible-lxc-rpc

Change-Id: I70b8ea460bba1649ea2a6ee0b2b98d00ce62ac13

commit_message:
Add dependency for keystone admin role before creating neutron resources

In some cases it's possible for keystone::roles::admin
to be processed after neutron attempts to create resources
which will result in the deployment failing


Closes-Bug: #1385491

Change-Id: I0e6454cee1d15b2e80382c18160ef7158e89284d

subject: Subnet delete for IPv6 SLAAC should not require prior port disassoc
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-25 12:01:08.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/test_db_plugin.py', 'neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/63b43376b3818a28af496d3a6f4e6957df9427f2', 'message': "Subnet delete for IPv6 SLAAC should not require prior port disassoc

With the current Neutron implementation, a subnet cannot be deleted
until all associated IP addresses have been remove from ports (via
port update) or the associated ports/VMs have been deleted.

In the case of SLAAC-enabled subnets, however, it's not feasible to
require removal of SLAAC-generated addresses individually from each
associated port before deleting a subnet because of the multicast
nature of RA messages. For SLAAC-enabled subnets, the processing of
subnet delete requests needs to be changed so that these subnets will
be allowed to be deleted, and all ports get disassociated from their
corresponding SLAAC IP address, when there are ports existing on
the SLAAC subnet.

Change-Id: I281f5a1553248e09174dc49d0a42aef4b5c44bee
Closes-Bug: 1393435
(cherry picked from commit ce5e95723925b0d7750bb3daa5be54765985cc30)
"}]
commit_message:
Subnet delete for IPv6 SLAAC should not require prior port disassoc

With the current Neutron implementation, a subnet cannot be deleted
until all associated IP addresses have been remove from ports (via
port update) or the associated ports/VMs have been deleted.

In the case of SLAAC-enabled subnets, however, it's not feasible to
require removal of SLAAC-generated addresses individually from each
associated port before deleting a subnet because of the multicast
nature of RA messages. For SLAAC-enabled subnets, the processing of
subnet delete requests needs to be changed so that these subnets will
be allowed to be deleted, and all ports get disassociated from their
corresponding SLAAC IP address, when there are ports existing on
the SLAAC subnet.

Change-Id: I281f5a1553248e09174dc49d0a42aef4b5c44bee
Closes-Bug: 1393435
(cherry picked from commit ce5e95723925b0d7750bb3daa5be54765985cc30)

commit_message:
Convert all incoming protocol numbers to string

PostgreSQL is more sensitive for types than MySQL when it selects
something from columns in database. So it fails when it tries to
select from string field comparing with integer value.

Added unit test to verify conversion of protocol numbers to
strings.

Closes-bug:#1381379

(cherry picked from commit bc34f26302faea116be7e61051c32f8787530836)

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/unit/test_extension_security_group.py

Change-Id: I0a29595403a07c66888871088d5549705a097f68
(cherry picked from commit c00b4b31276f9ae21fa0a7a213391277bda4cfa7)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/23/137423/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Deal with uppercase MAC address in register-nodes

Ironic will downcase all MAC addresses that are registered, so if
the node description uses uppercase MAC addresses, they will not
be matched. Lowercase when checking MACs against the node mapping
to sort this out.

Change-Id: I322e5d9eeb3ed85dd42d67caff8c61cea8c23856
Closes-Bug: #1394084

commit_message:
Pin oslo.messaging to stable/icehouse branch

When using the master branch with stable/icehouse, there is
a mismatch in requirements resulting in the following:
"'oslo.middleware' is not a global requirement but it should be,
  something went wrong"

This error does not occur if oslo.messaging is pinned to its
stable/icehouse branch.

Change-Id: I3b0b628756e48bdf0571fccaeff979086c08cff5

commit_message:
Add aliases for debug levels in rally.log

In Rally, we wrap the standard logging module with our own rally.log
module. This leads to ugle statements like logging.logging.INFO in some
places of Rally, because the logging levels are defined in the standard
logging module, which is, in turn, imported in rally.log.

Change-Id: I89be56592fe1a542e21e105ead17aafbc4b2319f

$ for file in `find glance -name '*\.py' -exec grep -wl auth_tok "{}" \;` ; \

commit_message:
Make RequestContext use auth_token (not auth_tok)

The RequestContext class from oslo-incubator uses 'auth_token'.
Glance's RequestContext uses 'auth_tok' -- which is inconsistent.

glance_store currently uses the oslo 'auth_token'.

We should not assume a 1-1 mapping from the glance_store to glance,
nor should we have glance_store support both 'auth_token' and
'auth_tok'. Therefore Glance should be updated to use 'auth_token'.

This change was generated automatically with:

$ for file in `find glance -name '*\.py' -exec grep -wl auth_tok "{}" \;` ; \
  do sed --in-place 's/\<auth_tok\>/auth_token/g' $file ; done

In addition, the set_auth_token function was removed. This had been used
by Nova to work around the auth_tok <-> auth_token inconsistency, but
was removed in mid-2012 as part of the move to python-glanceclient so
is no longer needed.

In conjuction with other changes this fixes image upload when
using the multi-tenant Swift store.

Change-Id: Ic8a5f44088990fd8f6290a5622b823f59ef365fc
Partial-bug: #1385213
(cherry picked from commit cc7ae2abd5c67b5573ca609e27c79d5c4f9a528d)

commit_message:
SoftwareDeployments make servers property updateable

Allow the servers list to be updated, which will cause an update
of the resource group instead of replacing it.

This looks inconvenient to test in the unit tests due to needing
to create a coupled nested stack (which will further impede the
decouple-nested work), so I'll post a followup patch with a
functional test instead, if that's viewed as acceptable.

Change-Id: I1714d2cef2d0edbeb82c16e5a83acc458009bd47
Closes-Bug: #1389178
(cherry picked from commit 218e1038f2828258eaf1e15d85cf074697f851a9)

subject: StackResource consider files in implementation_signature
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-19 17:30:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/d67c2a4e1ccb94379b3bbdfd98d3f59908645f7f', 'message': "StackResource consider files in implementation_signature

Currently, if the definition of something changes further down
the tree (beyond the template in the StackResource itself in a
more deeply nested template, e.g a provider resource in a
provider resource), we don't recurse on update, so the changes
are not reflected correctly on update.

So modify the definition part of the StackResource implementation
signature so we include both the resource template and the files
map, so we recurse whenver the files content has changed.

Note, on upgrade the first stack update of nested stacks after
this change will update even if no changes have occurred, because
the signature will change.  This should be a no-op other than
the stacks going UPDATE_COMPLETE.

Change-Id: Iff3ecfbe410e47e31f78e111065888b7fd2ddd00
Partial-Bug: #1389499

commit_message:
StackResource consider files in implementation_signature

Currently, if the definition of something changes further down
the tree (beyond the template in the StackResource itself in a
more deeply nested template, e.g a provider resource in a
provider resource), we don't recurse on update, so the changes
are not reflected correctly on update.

So modify the definition part of the StackResource implementation
signature so we include both the resource template and the files
map, so we recurse whenver the files content has changed.

Note, on upgrade the first stack update of nested stacks after
this change will update even if no changes have occurred, because
the signature will change.  This should be a no-op other than
the stacks going UPDATE_COMPLETE.

Change-Id: Iff3ecfbe410e47e31f78e111065888b7fd2ddd00
Partial-Bug: #1389499
(cherry picked from commit 32b4988ae5a3720e8a8c6edd2521d1dc659ad971)

commit_message:
Make metadata server use Instance.get_flavor()

This removes the use of extract_flavor() from the metadata server.

Related to blueprint flavor-from-sysmeta-to-blob

Change-Id: I06373f02a693d5fa9ad5acfe4e268a5fdbd5bac8

commit_message:
Fix problem with compare algorithm

The logic was missing removed tests except for
1st one.

Improved diff unit test to verify number of diffs
per type (removed_tests, new_tests, value_changed)

Change-Id: I45fd77dbc31a255e0bdc33c6b8b2ebd1c9f088ed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/82/137182/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove stable compatibility jobs from capped libs

We are introducing version caps on libraries in stable branches, so we
no longer need to test updates to their master branches against the
stable branches of applications.

Change-Id: Ifc57ae7201b180cf3cf52ff56ab280086f7b939a

commit_message:
Adding support for query filtering to list() calls

Each of the list() methods now supports an extra
parameter, search_opts, which is a dict that will
contain search fields and values to limit the result
sets.  The changes here will also rely upon changes
to the Sahara service to support query-style
parameters.

Change-Id: I26986cbc153c3f8ad74b52d91086afbdfbd93926
Implements: bp enable-result-filtering
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-saharaclient refs/changes/86/135086/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def list(self): return self._list('/cluster-templates', 'cluster_templates')

subject: Add middleware.catch_errors shim for Kilo
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-25 10:02:45.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/common/middleware/catch_errors.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/ce8f8fa4811a2d18a97e6f06208930dd227045ea', 'message': 'Add middleware.catch_errors shim for Kilo

A deprecation warning was added to oslo-incubator for Juno, but
unfortunately not to any of the projects actually using it.

Since this module is referenced in the api paste config, removing
the module from the project trees without deprecation warning
constitutes an operator-visible backwards incompatible change,
which AIUI is not allowed.

This mitigates the lack of deprecation period by adding a shim for
Kilo, which projects can sync before switching their paste defaults
to point to oslo.middleware, we can then remove the shim in L.

The module is currently used in Neutron and Swift api-paste.ini files.

Change-Id: I4ebd1baac2e3a58d086b6d227662787d42655da9
Related-Bug: #1380629
'}]
commit_message:
Add middleware.catch_errors shim for Kilo

A deprecation warning was added to oslo-incubator for Juno, but
unfortunately not to any of the projects actually using it.

Since this module is referenced in the api paste config, removing
the module from the project trees without deprecation warning
constitutes an operator-visible backwards incompatible change,
which AIUI is not allowed.

This mitigates the lack of deprecation period by adding a shim for
Kilo, which projects can sync before switching their paste defaults
to point to oslo.middleware, we can then remove the shim in L.

The module is currently used in Neutron and Swift api-paste.ini files.

Change-Id: I4ebd1baac2e3a58d086b6d227662787d42655da9
Related-Bug: #1380629
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/99/136999/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Compatibility shim for Kilo, while operators migrate to oslo.middleware.""" from oslo.middleware import catch_errors from openstack.common import versionutils @versionutils.deprecated(as_of=versionutils.deprecated.KILO, in_favor_of='oslo.middleware.CatchErrors') class CatchErrorsMiddleware(catch_errors.CatchErrors): pass

commit_message:
Reuse already built docker build targets

Makes use of donefiles for each docker container
so that complex builds can reuse the docker targets
on subsequent makes.

Change-Id: I1bb238baad908777ec538222daf8334fe7a414ec
Closes-Bug: #1395761

commit_message:
compute/v2 server metadata and server meta resouce

Change-Id: If361abaf76d13da343fd37b32b833eaf32c2ac19
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/35/116735/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import testtools from openstack.compute.v2 import server_metadata FAKE_SERVER_ID = 'cervidae' FAKE_KEY = 'cervus' FAKE_VALUE = 'canadensis' FAKE_KEY2 = 'odocoileus' FAKE_VALUE2 = 'hemionus' EXAMPLE = { 'server_id': FAKE_SERVER_ID, FAKE_KEY: FAKE_VALUE, } FAKE_RESPONSE = {"metadata": {FAKE_KEY: FAKE_VALUE, FAKE_KEY2: FAKE_VALUE2}} class TestServerMetadata(testtools.TestCase): def test_basic(self): sot = server_metadata.ServerMetadata() self.assertEqual('metadata', sot.resource_key) self.assertEqual(None, sot.resources_key) self.assertEqual('/servers/%(server_id)s/metadata', sot.base_path) self.assertEqual('compute', sot.service.service_type) self.assertTrue(sot.allow_create) self.assertTrue(sot.allow_retrieve) self.assertTrue(sot.allow_update) self.assertFalse(sot.allow_delete) self.assertFalse(sot.allow_list) def test_make_it(self): sot = server_metadata.ServerMetadata(EXAMPLE) self.assertEqual(EXAMPLE['server_id'], sot.server_id) self.assertEqual(FAKE_VALUE, sot[FAKE_KEY]) def test_create(self): resp = mock.Mock() resp.body = FAKE_RESPONSE sess = mock.Mock() sess.put = mock.MagicMock() sess.put.return_value = resp sot = server_metadata.ServerMetadata(EXAMPLE.copy()) sot.create(sess) url = '/servers/' + FAKE_SERVER_ID + '/metadata' body = {"metadata": {FAKE_KEY: FAKE_VALUE}} sess.put.assert_called_with(url, service=sot.service, json=body) self.assertEqual(FAKE_SERVER_ID, sot.server_id) self.assertEqual(FAKE_VALUE, sot[FAKE_KEY]) def test_get(self): resp = mock.Mock() resp.body = FAKE_RESPONSE sess = mock.Mock() sess.get = mock.MagicMock() sess.get.return_value = resp sot = server_metadata.ServerMetadata(EXAMPLE.copy()) sot.get(sess) url = '/servers/' + FAKE_SERVER_ID + '/metadata' sess.get.assert_called_with(url, service=sot.service) self.assertEqual(FAKE_SERVER_ID, sot.server_id) self.assertEqual(FAKE_VALUE, sot[FAKE_KEY]) self.assertEqual(FAKE_VALUE2, sot[FAKE_KEY2]) def test_update(self): resp = mock.Mock() resp.body = FAKE_RESPONSE sess = mock.Mock() sess.put = mock.MagicMock() sess.put.return_value = resp sot = server_metadata.ServerMetadata(EXAMPLE.copy()) sot.update(sess) url = '/servers/' + FAKE_SERVER_ID + '/metadata' body = {"metadata": {FAKE_KEY: FAKE_VALUE}} sess.put.assert_called_with(url, service=sot.service, json=body) self.assertEqual(FAKE_SERVER_ID, sot.server_id) self.assertEqual(FAKE_VALUE, sot[FAKE_KEY])

commit_message:
Configure ENABLED_QUOTA_GROUPS for Horizon

Configure local_settings.py according to 'nova_quota' parameter
from Fuel settings. We need to use 'scope.lookupvar' in template
here for compatibility reasons with future upstream sync:

https://review.openstack.org/132688

We're going to use custom local_settings template after upgrade,
to avoid unnecessary changes in 'horizon' community module.

Change-Id: I647430b1799b752a0e6c44b363830d78c5bb3d9a
Related-bug: #1332457
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/91/137391/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $nova_quota = false,

subject: Fix metadata proxy start problem for v6-v4 network
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-25 23:08:06.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/dhcp_agent.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/test_dhcp_agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8b5c08b35e75de6e09b75ed01120b6fdedb9125f', 'message': 'Fix metadata proxy start problem for v6-v4 network

Commit 1b66e11b5d8c0b3de0610ca02c3e10b6f64ae375 introduces
a new problem that metadata proxy will not be started when
an isolated network contains ipv6 subnet with dhcp enabled
and a ipv4 subnet.

This fix separates the checks to enable dhcp and enable metadata
so metadata proxy can be started if there is ipv4 subnet exists
in the network with metadata enabled.

Change-Id: If26806083db225e9ab30d75fa6c728ce99a7cafe
Closes-Bug: 1392564
(cherry picked from commit 4c128c351589ef9f2fc1e084c655a97bdbbda7ce)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix metadata proxy start problem for v6-v4 network

Commit 1b66e11b5d8c0b3de0610ca02c3e10b6f64ae375 introduces
a new problem that metadata proxy will not be started when
an isolated network contains ipv6 subnet with dhcp enabled
and a ipv4 subnet.

This fix separates the checks to enable dhcp and enable metadata
so metadata proxy can be started if there is ipv4 subnet exists
in the network with metadata enabled.

Change-Id: If26806083db225e9ab30d75fa6c728ce99a7cafe
Closes-Bug: 1392564
(cherry picked from commit 4c128c351589ef9f2fc1e084c655a97bdbbda7ce)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/38/137238/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fake_network_ipv6_ipv4 = dhcp.NetModel(True, dict( id='12345678-1234-5678-1234567890ab', tenant_id='aaaaaaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaaaaaaaaaa', admin_state_up=True, subnets=[fake_ipv6_subnet, fake_subnet1], ports=[fake_port1])) def test_enable_dhcp_helper_enable_metadata_ipv6_ipv4_network(self): self._enable_dhcp_helper(fake_network_ipv6_ipv4, enable_isolated_metadata=True, is_isolated_network=True) def test_enable_dhcp_helper_driver_failure_ipv6_ipv4_network(self): self.plugin.get_network_info.return_value = fake_network_ipv6_ipv4 self.call_driver.return_value = False cfg.CONF.set_override('enable_isolated_metadata', True) with mock.patch.object( self.dhcp, 'enable_isolated_metadata_proxy') as enable_metadata: self.dhcp.enable_dhcp_helper(fake_network_ipv6_ipv4.id) self.plugin.assert_has_calls( [mock.call.get_network_info(fake_network_ipv6_ipv4.id)]) self.call_driver.assert_called_once_with('enable', fake_network_ipv6_ipv4) self.assertFalse(self.cache.called) self.assertFalse(enable_metadata.called) self.assertFalse(self.external_process.called)
